page.title: Bill Brown with the Australian cricket team in England in 1948

revisions.rev:
{{Infobox cricketer tour biography | playername = Bill Brown | female = | image = BillBrown2.jpg | country = Australia | fullname = William Alfred Brown | nickname = | living = | partialdates = | dayofbirth = 31 | monthofbirth = 7 | yearofbirth = 1912 | placeofbirth = [[Toowoomba, Queensland|Toowoomba]] | countryofbirth = Australia | dayofdeath = 16 | monthofdeath = 3 | yearofdeath = 2008 | placeofdeath = [[Brisbane, Queensland|Brisbane]] | countryofdeath = Australia | heightft = | heightinch = | heightm = 1.76 | batting = Right-hand batsman | bowling = Right-arm [[off spin]] | role = Batsman | international = true | testdebutdate = 10 June | testdebutyear = 1948 | testdebutagainst = England | lasttestdate = 24 June | lasttestyear = 1948 | lasttestagainst = England | deliveries = balls | columns = 2 | column1 = [[test cricket|Tests]] | matches1 = 2 | runs1 = 73 | bat avg1 = 24.33 | 100s/50s1 = –/– | top score1 = 32 | deliveries1 = – | wickets1 = – | bowl avg1 = – | fivefor1 = – | tenfor1 = – | best bowling1 = – | catches/stumpings1 = 2/0 | column2 = [[First-class cricket|First-class]] | matches2 = 22 | runs2 = 1448 | bat avg2 = 57.92 | 100s/50s2 = 8/1 | top score2 = 200 | deliveries2 = 25 | wickets2 = 4 | bowl avg2 = 4.00 | fivefor2 = – | tenfor2 = – | best bowling2 = 4/16 | catches/stumpings2 = 16/0 | date= 12 December | year = 2007 | source = <ref name=o/> }}
[[Bill Brown (cricketer)|Bill Brown]] was a member of [[Donald Bradman]]'s famous [[Australian cricket team in England in 1948|Australian cricket team, which toured England in 1948]]. Bradman's men went through their 34 matches without defeat; this unprecedented feat by a Test side touring England earned them the sobriquet ''The Invincibles''.
An experienced right-handed [[batting order (cricket)|opening]] batsman, Brown was on his third visit to England, having first toured in 1934 before [[World War II]]. However, Brown's best years were lost to the war and by 1948 [[Sid Barnes]] and [[Arthur Morris]] had superseded him in the pecking order to become Australia's first-choice opening pair. Brown was selected as a reserve opener; this decision generated controversy among critics who believed he was past his best.
Bradman rotated the three openers in the tour matches, but Morris and Barnes were preferred in the Tests. Bradman accommodated Brown in his first-choice team by playing him out of position in the [[batting order (cricket)|middle order]] in the Tests. However, Brown appeared uncomfortable in the unfamiliar role, and was dropped after making 73 runs at a [[batting average]] of 24.33 in the first two Tests.
Despite his struggles in the Test arena, Brown had success in the tour matches as an opener. He scored 1,448 runs at 57.92 in all [[first-class cricket|first-class matches]], ranking fourth in both the aggregates and averages. He scored eight [[century (cricket)|centuries]], second only to Bradman, including 200 against [[Cambridge University Cricket Club|Cambridge University]]. However, Brown gained criticism for his slow batting. Following his omission from the Test team, Brown batted in a highly circumspect manner to increase the reliability and volume of his scoring. A very occasional [[off spin]] bowler, Brown took his career first-class best of 4/16 in his only stint with the ball, against the [[South of England cricket team|South of England]].
==Background== Brown had been a regular member of the Australian Test team since his debut in 1934, and immediately after [[World War II]], he captained Australia in the inaugural Test against [[New Zealand cricket team|New Zealand]].<ref name=az/> However, he was sidelined by injury in 1946–47 and [[Sid Barnes]] and [[Arthur Morris]] opened in the Tests, averaging 73.83 and 71.85 respectively.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Events/AUS/Marylebone_Cricket_Club_in_Australia_1946-47/t_Australia_Batting.html|title=Test Batting and Fielding for Australia Marylebone Cricket Club in Australia 1946/47 |publisher=[[CricketArchive]] |accessdate=2009-01-13}}</ref> Brown resumed his Test career in the following season, replacing Barnes, but he was dropped after scoring 29 runs in two Tests. Barnes then came in and made 139 runs in the next two Tests, including a 112 in the Fourth Test. Morris was then rested for the Fifth Test to allow Brown another chance to show his ability and make a case for continued national selection, and he made 99.<ref name=az/> In the Tests against [[India national cricket team|India]] during the season, Barnes, Morris and Brown had shared the opening duties; their batting averages were 43.00, 52.25 and 42.66 respectively.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Events/AUS/India_in_Australia_1947-48/t_Australia_Batting.html |title=Test Batting and Fielding for Australia India in Australia 1947/48 |publisher=[[CricketArchive]] |accessdate=2009-01-13}}</ref> In any case, Brown had done enough to [[Australian cricket team in England in 1948|tour England with ''The Invincibles'' in 1948]], his third trip there, although Barnes and Morris were the first-choice opening combination.<ref name="az"/>
==Early tour== Australia traditionally fielded its first-choice team in the tour opener, which was customarily against [[Worcestershire County Cricket Club|Worcestershire]].<ref name=haigh>{{Cite news| title=Gentrifying the game| first=Gideon | last=Haigh| authorlink=Gideon Haigh| url=http://www.cricinfo.com/ci/content/story/295893.html |publisher=[[Cricinfo]] |date=2007-05-26| accessdate=2007-06-01}}</ref> Brown gained selection, although Bradman batted him out of position in the middle order while Barnes and Morris opened. Brown came in 6/335 and scored 25 at a typically placid pace,<ref name=az/><ref name=worcs/> accumulating his runs at a lower [[strike rate]] than the other recognised batsmen. He was out with the score at 6/402 as Australia went on to [[declaration and forfeiture|declare]] at 8/462 and win by an innings.<ref name=worcs>{{Cite web |url = http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/18/18403.html |title = Worcestershire v Australians |publisher = [[CricketArchive]] |accessdate = 2008-12-18}}</ref>
In the next match against [[Leicestershire County Cricket Club|Leicestershire]], Bradman rested Morris, so Brown opened with Barnes. Brown scored 26 in an [[partnership (cricket)|opening stand]] of 46, as Australia amassed 448 and won by an innings.<ref name=o>{{Cite web |url = http://www.cricketarchive.com/cgi-bin/player_oracle_reveals_results2.cgi?playernumber=636&opponentmatch=exact&playername=John&resulttype=All&matchtype=All&teammatch=exact&startwicket=&homeawaytype=All&opponent=&endwicket=&wicketkeeper=&searchtype=InningsList&endscore=&playermatch=contains&branding=cricketarchive&captain=&endseason=1948&startscore=&team=&startseason=1948 |title = Player Oracle WA Brown 1948 |publisher = [[CricketArchive]] |accessdate = 2008-12-18}}</ref><ref name=leics>{{Cite web |url = http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/18/18406.html |title = Leicestershire v Australians |publisher = [[CricketArchive]] |accessdate = 2008-12-18}}</ref> [[File:SidBarnesHeadshot.jpg|thumb|Sid Barnes (pictured), one of Brown's opening partners during the tour.]] The Australians proceeded to play [[Yorkshire County Cricket Club|Yorkshire]] at [[Bradford]], on a [[sticky wicket|damp pitch]] suitable for [[spin bowling|slower bowling]].<ref name=o/><ref name=y>Fingleton, pp. 53–55.</ref> In the first innings, Brown took three catches from the bowling of [[Keith Miller]]—who had resorted to bowling [[off spin]]—as Yorkshire were bowled out for 71 in difficult batting conditions.<ref name=y/> Opening with Morris while Barnes was rested, Brown made 13 as the match remained finely balanced after Australia was bowled out for 101. Brown took another catch from Miller in the second innings as the hosts were bowled out for 89. Chasing 60 for victory, Brown fell to [[Frank Smailes]] for two as the Australian top order collapsed to 6/31—effectively seven wickets down with the injured [[Sam Loxton]] unable to bat—before scraping home by four wickets.<ref name=york>{{Cite web |url = http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/18/18412.html |title = Yorkshire v Australians |publisher = [[CricketArchive]] |accessdate = 2008-12-18}}</ref>
Brown was rested for the next match against [[Surrey County Cricket Club|Surrey]], which Australia won by an innings.<ref name=o/><ref name=sched/> After the first four matches, five Australians hade made centuries, and another had passed fifty.<ref name=worcs/><ref name=leics/><ref name=york/><ref name=sched/><ref name=surrey>{{Cite web |url = http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/18/18422.html |title = Surrey v Australians |publisher = [[CricketArchive]] |accessdate = 2008-12-18}}</ref> Brown had scored only 66 runs with a highest score of 26,<ref name=o/> while Morris and Barnes, the incumbent openers, had scored 223 and 298 runs with a century and fifty apiece.<ref name=worcs/><ref name=leics/><ref name=york/><ref name=sched/><ref name=surrey/><ref name="morris">{{Cite web| title= Wisden 1949 – Arthur Morris |url=http://www.cricinfo.com/wisdenalmanack/content/story/234445.html| year= 1949 |accessdate=2007-05-21| publisher= [[Wisden]]}}</ref>
Brown was recalled for the match against [[Cambridge University Cricket Club|Cambridge University]],<ref name="sched">{{Cite web|title=Matches, Australia tour of England, Apr-Sep 1948 |url=http://www.cricinfo.com/invincibles/engine/series/61329.html |publisher=[[Cricinfo]] |accessdate=2008-07-16}}</ref> opening with Morris while Barnes rested. After putting on 64 for the opening wicket with Morris, Brown added 176 for the second wicket with [[Ron Hamence]]. He added a further 140 for the fourth wicket with [[Lindsay Hassett]], who was captaining the team while Bradman rested himself. Brown top-scored with 200 and Hassett declared when his double-centurion was out with the score at 4/414. Australia went on to win by an innings.<ref>{{Cite web |url = http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/18/18423.html |title = Cambridge University v Australians |publisher = [[CricketArchive]] |accessdate = 2007-12-26}}</ref> In the following match against [[Essex County Cricket Club|Essex]], Brown opened with Barnes while Morris was rested. The pair put on 145 in 97 minutes—the highest opening stand by the Australians on the tour to that point<ref>Fingleton, p. 66.</ref>—before Barnes was out [[hit wicket]]. In the meantime, Brown had reached 50 in 90 minutes. Bradman came in and he and Brown accelerated to put on a second-wicket partnership of 219 in 90 minutes, before the latter was out for 153 from three hours of batting with the score at 2/364. Brown had scored his last 100 runs in less than 90 minutes.<ref>Fingleton, p. 67.</ref> Australia went on to score 721 runs on the first day, the highest number of runs amassed in one day of first-class cricket, before completing victory by an innings and 451 runs, their largest winning margin for the tour.<ref>{{Cite web |url = http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/18/18429.html |title = Essex v Australians |publisher = [[CricketArchive]] |accessdate = 2007-12-26}}</ref><ref>Perry (2005), p. 226.</ref> Opening with Morris while Barnes was rested, Brown completed his third century in as many innings with 108 against [[Oxford University Cricket Club|Oxford University]], after putting on an opening stand of 139.<ref name=o/><ref name=sched/><ref>{{Cite web |url = http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/18/18444.html |title = Oxford University v Australians |publisher = [[CricketArchive]] |accessdate = 2007-12-26}}</ref> This meant that he had scored 461 runs in eight days of cricket, and put him atop the batting aggregates, ahead of Bradman.<ref name=o/><ref name=sched/><ref name="f70"/> Australia went on to complete their fourth successive innings victory.<ref name=sched/>
The next match was against the [[Marylebone Cricket Club]] (MCC) at [[Lord's]]. The MCC fielded seven players who would represent England in the Tests,<ref name=sco1>{{Cite web| title = 1st Test England v Australia at Nottingham Jun 10–15 1948|url=http://www.cricinfo.com/ci/engine/match/62685.html|publisher= [[Cricinfo]]|accessdate=2007-12-12}}</ref><ref name=sco2>{{Cite web| title = 2nd Test England v Australia at Lord's Jun 24–29 1948|url=http://www.cricinfo.com/ci/engine/match/62686.html|publisher= [[Cricinfo]]|accessdate=2007-12-12}}</ref><ref name=sco3>{{Cite web| title = 3rd Test England v Australia at Manchester Jul 8–13 1948|url=http://www.cricinfo.com/ci/engine/match/62687.html|publisher= [[Cricinfo]]|accessdate=2007-12-12}}</ref><ref name=sco4>{{Cite web| title = 4th Test England v Australia at Leeds Jul 22–27 1948|url=http://www.cricinfo.com/ci/engine/match/62688.html|publisher= [[Cricinfo]]|accessdate=2007-12-12}}</ref><ref name=sco5>{{Cite web| title = 5th Test England v Australia at The Oval Aug 14–18 1948|url=http://www.cricinfo.com/ci/engine/match/62689.html|publisher= [[Cricinfo]]|accessdate=2007-12-12}}</ref><ref name=mcc>{{Cite web |url = http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/18/18451.html |title = MCC v Australians |publisher = [[CricketArchive]] |accessdate = 2008-12-18}}</ref> and were basically a full strength Test team, while Australia fielded their first-choice team. Bradman installed Barnes and Morris as his preferred opening pair, while Brown batted out of position at No. 6. Barring one change in the bowling department, the same team lined up in the First Test, with the top six batsmen in the same positions.<ref name=sco1/><ref name=mcc/> It was a chance for players from both sides to gain a psychological advantage, but Brown failed to capitalise. He came to the crease with the score at 4/280 to join [[Keith Miller]] and scored 26 in a stand of 63 before being dismissed as Australia amassed 552 and won by an innings.<ref name=o/> This was followed by Australia's first non-victory of the tour, against [[Lancashire County Cricket Club|Lancashire]], a draw for which Brown was rested.<ref name=o/><ref name=sched/>
Brown returned for the following match, which was against [[Nottinghamshire County Cricket Club|Nottinghamshire]], and added 122 to register his fourth century in less than three weeks. Australia made 400 but the hosts hung on for a draw in the second innings.<ref name=o/><ref name="sched"/><ref>{{Cite web |url = http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/18/18467.html |title = Nottinghamshire v Australians |publisher = [[CricketArchive]] |accessdate = 2007-12-26}}</ref> In the next match against [[Hampshire County Cricket Club|Hampshire]], Brown opened with Barnes and made a [[duck (cricket)|duck]] as Australia were dismissed for 117 on a damp pitch in reply to the home side's 195. It was the first time the tourists had conceded a first innings during the summer.<ref name=sched/><ref name=hants>{{Cite web |url = http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/18/18473.html |title = Hampshire v Australians |publisher = [[CricketArchive]] |accessdate = 2008-12-18}}</ref> Hampshire were subsequently bowled out in their second innings for 103 to leave Australia a target of 182. This time Barnes fell for a duck, and Brown anchored Australia to an eight-wicket win with an unbeaten 81 after a century second-wicket partnership with [[Ian Johnson (cricketer)|Ian Johnson]].<ref name=o/><ref name=hants/> The final match before the First Test was against [[Sussex County Cricket Club|Sussex]]. Opening with Morris, Brown played second fiddle, accumulating 44 as the pair put on an opening stand of 153. Morris went on to 184 and Australia declared at 5/549 before completing another innings victory.<ref name=sched/><ref name=sussex>{{Cite web |url = http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/18/18489.html |title = Sussex v Australians |publisher = [[CricketArchive]] |accessdate = 2008-12-18}}</ref>
==First Test== {{Main|First Test, 1948 Ashes series}}
Up to this point, Brown—who was on his third tour of England—had scored 800 runs on tour at an average of 72.72, with a double century, three other centuries and 81 [[not out]],<ref name=o/><ref name=az/> In contrast, middle-order batsman [[Neil Harvey]] struggled in the initial stages of his first tour of England. Harvey failed to pass 25 in his first six innings,<ref>Perry (2002), p. 101.</ref> and although he had scored an unbeaten 100 against Sussex, he had totalled only 296 runs at 42.29.<ref name=harvey>{{Cite web |url = http://www.cricketarchive.com/cgi-bin/player_oracle_reveals_results2.cgi?playernumber=813&opponentmatch=exact&playername=John&resulttype=All&matchtype=All&teammatch=exact&startwicket=&homeawaytype=All&opponent=&endwicket=&wicketkeeper=&searchtype=InningsList&endscore=&playermatch=contains&branding=cricketarchive&captain=&endseason=1948&startscore=&team=&startseason=1948 |title = Player Oracle RN Harvey 1948 |publisher = [[CricketArchive]] |accessdate = 2008-12-18}}</ref> As a result, Brown gained selection in the First Test at [[Trent Bridge]], batting out of position in the middle order while Barnes and Morris opened, whereas Harvey was dropped despite making a century in Australia's most recent Test against India.<ref name="sco1">{{Cite web| title = 1st Test England v Australia at Nottingham Jun 10-15 1948|url=http://www.cricinfo.com/ci/engine/match/62685.html|publisher= [[Cricinfo]]|accessdate=2007-12-12}}</ref><ref name="auslist">{{Cite web|url=http://stats.cricinfo.com/guru?sdb=team;team=AUS;class=testteam;filter=basic;opposition=0;notopposition=0;decade=0;homeaway=0;continent=0;country=0;notcountry=0;groundid=0;season=0;startdefault=1877-03-15;start=1877-03-15;enddefault=2007-11-20;end=2007-11-20;tourneyid=0;finals=0;daynight=0;toss=0;scheduledovers=0;scheduleddays=0;innings=0;followon=0;result=0;seriesresult=0;captainid=0;recent=;viewtype=resultlist;runslow=;runshigh=;wicketslow=;wicketshigh=;ballslow=;ballshigh=;overslow=;overshigh=;bpo=0;batevent=;conclow=;conchigh=;takenlow=;takenhigh=;ballsbowledlow=;ballsbowledhigh=;oversbowledlow=;oversbowledhigh=;bpobowled=0;bowlevent=;submit=1;.cgifields=viewtype |title=Statsguru – Australia – Tests – Results list |publisher=[[Cricinfo]] |accessdate=2007-12-21}}</ref><ref>Perry (2002), p. 100.</ref>
England batted first and made 165, with Brown prominent in the field. Early on the first day of play, Brown caught England opener [[Cyril Washbrook]] on the run at the [[Fielding (cricket)#Fielding position names and locations|fine leg boundary]] after the batsman had attempted to [[Batting (cricket)#Pull and hook|hook]] a [[Ray Lindwall]] [[bouncer (cricket)|bouncer]],<ref name="sco1"/><ref name="report1"/><ref name=f84>Fingleton, p. 84.</ref> leaving England at 2/15 after 41 minutes of play.<ref name=sco1/> He later made a series of one-handed stops in the field, helping to keep the pressure on the batsmen.<ref name=f85>Fingleton, p. 85.</ref><ref name=a31>Arlott, p. 31.</ref> Brown took his second catch of the innings to remove [[Alec Bedser]], who had featured in a rearguard fightback to help take England to 165 after they had fallen to 8/74.<ref name=sco1/>
On the second day, Barnes and Bradman took the score to 1/121 before Barnes and Miller were dismissed without further addition to the score.<ref name="sco1"/><ref name="report1"/><ref name="p235">Perry (2005), p. 235.</ref> All the while, Australia had been scoring slowly, as they would throughout the day. Brown came in at No. 5 to join Bradman, but he had played most of his career as an opening batsman and he looked uncomfortable in the middle order,<ref name=f91/> but Bradman brought him in ahead of Hassett as the new ball was due and Brown was used to starting his innings against pace bowlers and a new ball.<ref name=o39>O'Reilly, p. 39.</ref> English captain [[Norman Yardley]] removed [[Jim Laker]] from the attack and took the second new ball. Bradman struck his first boundary in over 80 minutes and the [[run rate]] picked up somewhat, prompting England to revert to slower bowling.<ref name=a37>Arlott, p. 37.</ref> Australia passed England's total before Yardley brought himself on to bowl and trapped Brown—who was attempting to push the ball to mid-on—[[leg before wicket]] (lbw) with an [[off cutter]] in his first over.<ref name="report1"/><ref name=f91/> This ended a 64-run stand in 58 minutes and left Australia at 4/185.<ref name=sco1/><ref name="report1">{{Cite web|title= First Test Match England v Australia |work= [[Wisden Cricketers' Almanack]] |year=1949 |url=http://www.cricinfo.com/wisdenalmanack/content/story/152894.html |accessdate=2008-07-02 |publisher=[[Wisden]]}}</ref> Following the departure of Brown, the scoring slowed as Bradman changed the team strategy to one of attempting to bat only once.<ref name=o39/> Australia eventually reached 509, and after England compiled 441 in their second innings, Brown was not needed as Australia made the 98 runs required victory for the loss of only two wickets.<ref name="sco1"/>
Between Tests, Brown was rested for the match against [[Northamptonshire County Cricket Club|Northamptonshire]], which Australia won by an innings.<ref name=o/><ref name=sched/> He returned for the second fixture against [[Yorkshire County Cricket Club|Yorkshire]]. Opening with Barnes, Brown made 19 as Australia took a 43-run first innings lead. In the second innings, Brown top-scored with 113. He combined with Bradman to add 154 runs for the second wicket as the match petered into a draw.<ref name=york2/> In a patient and restrained display, Brown took four hours to make his century. Following his controversial selection for the tour, Brown was attempting to justify his position in the team by accumulating a large amount of runs, but earned criticism for being too dour.<ref name="f194"/> However, the century was enough to see him retain his middle-order position for the Second Test at Lord's, where Australia fielded an unchanged team.<ref name=sco1/><ref name=sco2/><ref name=york2>{{Cite web |url = http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/18/18526.html |title = Yorkshire v Australians |publisher = [[CricketArchive]] |accessdate = 2007-12-26}}</ref><ref name="times"/> Former Test leg spinner and teammate [[Bill O'Reilly (cricketer)|Bill O'Reilly]]—who was in England as a journalist&mdsah;criticised the selection of Brown, who had appeared to be noticeably uncomfortable in the unfamiliar role. He said that despite Brown's unbeaten double century in his previous Test at Lord's in 1938, [[Sam Loxton]] and [[Neil Harvey]] had better claims to selection.<ref name=o59>O'Reilly, p. 59.</ref>
==Second Test== {{Main|Second Test, 1948 Ashes series}}
Australia won the toss and batted first at the home of cricket. Centurion Morris fell at 3/166 and new batsman Miller was trapped lbw for four shortly after.<ref name="p240">Perry (2005), p. 240.</ref> Brown came in at 4/173 and helped [[Lindsay Hassett]] rebuild the innings after the two quick wickets. Both men scored slowly, averaging more than three and half minutes for each run.<ref name="sco2"/><ref name="report2">{{Cite web|title= Second Test Match England v Australia |work= [[Wisden Cricketers' Almanack]] |year=1949 |url=http://www.cricinfo.com/wisdenalmanack/content/story/152895.html |publisher=[[Wisden]] |accessdate=2008-07-02}}</ref> After putting on a partnership of 43, Hassett was bowled by Yardley, who then trapped Brown for 24 to leave Australia stumbling at 6/225. Brown had hit two consecutive half-volleys off his pads through the leg side for four, and attempted a third boundary in a row to a similar delivery.<Ref name=sco2/> However, this third delivery came off the pitch more quickly and beat Brown for pace.<ref name=f110>Fingleton, p. 175.</ref> Australia managed to avoid further collapse a counterattack from the tail saw them to 350 before they bowled England out for 215.<ref name="report2"/> The tourists batted much more productively in the second innings in ideal weather on the third day.<ref name="report2"/> Brown joined Miller after Bradman fell at 4/329; Australia had lost 3/33 but steadied to reach stumps at 343 without further loss, with Brown on seven.<ref name="sco2"/><ref name="p241"/> After the rest day, Australia resumed with a lead of 478 runs and six wickets in hand. The morning was punctuated by three rain stoppages. Just ten minutes after the start, heavy rain intervened. The weather cleared and Miller and Brown moved to lunch on 63 and 32 respectively, with Australia at 4/409.<ref>Fingleton, pp. 120–121.</ref> In 88 minutes of play, Australia had added 117 runs.<ref name="report2"/> Brown was caught behind from [[Alec Coxon]] after lunch without adding to his score for 32, after an 87-run partnership with Miller, with the score at 5/416. Bradman eventually declared at 7/460, 595 runs ahead. It would take a world record chase from England to win the match.<ref name="sco2"/><ref name="p241">Perry (2005), p. 241.</ref> The home team lost wickets regularly and fell for 186 to lose by 409 runs.<ref name="sco2"/> Although part of a successful team, Brown was unable to replicate the centuries he made in each of his two previous Tests at Lordâs on the preceding tours, and it was to be the last Test of his career.<ref name="testlist"/>
The next match was against [[Surrey County Cricket Club|Surrey]] and started the day after the Test. Brown injured a finger while fielding in the first innings, so he was unable to bat in Australia's first innings. In the second innings, Australia's makeshift openers Harvey and [[Sam Loxton]] chased down the 122 runs for victory to complete a 10-wicket win in less than an hour.<ref name=o/><ref name=sched/><ref>{{Cite book | title = [[Wisden Cricketers' Almanack]] | edition = 1949 | publisher = [[Wisden]] | chapter = Australians in England, 1948 | pages = 237–238 }}</ref>
==Dropped== {{Main|Third Test, 1948 Ashes series| Fourth Test, 1948 Ashes series | Fifth Test, 1948 Ashes series }}
Brown was rested for the following match against [[Gloucestershire County Cricket Club|Gloucestershire]] before the Third Test.<ref name=o/><ref name=sched/> Loxton scored 159 not out, featuring in two century partnerships and propelling Australia to 7/774 declared, which was its highest score of the tour and laid the foundation for an innings victory. Loxtonâs effort was enough to oust Brown from his middle-order position for the Third Test at [[Old Trafford (cricket ground)|Old Trafford]].<ref name="sched"/><ref name=sco2/><ref name=sco3/><ref name=testlist>{{Cite web|url=http://stats.cricinfo.com/guru?sdb=player;playerid=636;class=testplayer;filter=basic;team=0;opposition=0;notopposition=0;season=0;homeaway=0;continent=0;country=0;notcountry=0;groundid=0;startdefault=1934-06-08;start=1934-06-08;enddefault=1948-06-29;end=1948-06-29;tourneyid=0;finals=0;daynight=0;toss=0;scheduledovers=0;scheduleddays=0;innings=0;result=0;followon=0;seriesresult=0;captain=0;keeper=0;dnp=0;recent=;viewtype=aro_list;runslow=;runshigh=;batposition=0;dismissal=0;bowposition=0;ballslow=;ballshigh=;bpof=0;overslow=;overshigh=;conclow=;conchigh=;wicketslow=;wicketshigh=;dismissalslow=;dismissalshigh=;caughtlow=;caughthigh=;caughttype=0;stumpedlow=;stumpedhigh=;csearch=;submit=1;.cgifields=viewtype| accessdate=2007-11-30| title=Statsguru – WA Brown – Tests – Innings by innings list |publisher=[[Cricinfo]]}}</ref><ref name="p176">Perry (2000), p. 176.</ref> According to OâReilly, Brown had appeared out of place in the middle-order because he was used to the openerâs classical role of defending against and wearing down the opening bowlers, rather than attacking.<ref name=o84>O'Reilly, p. 84.</ref> During the Test, which was drawn, Barnes was injured and [[off spin]]ner [[Ian Johnson (cricketer)|Ian Johnson]] was used as a makeshift opener as Morris was the only specialist left after Brownâs omission.<ref name="report3">{{Cite web|title= Third Test Match England v Australia |work= [[Wisden Cricketers' Almanack]] |year=1949 |url=http://www.cricinfo.com/wisdenalmanack/content/story/152896.html |accessdate=2008-07-02 |publisher=[[Wisden]]}}</ref><ref name=report4/><ref>{{Cite web |url = http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/18/18558.html |title = Gloucestershire v Australians |publisher = [[CricketArchive]] |accessdate = 2007-12-26}}</ref> Afterwards, Brown managed only eight as Australia defeated [[Middlesex County Cricket Club|Middlesex]] by ten wickets in their only county match between Tests.<ref name=o/><ref name=sched/>
Barnes was still unavailable for the Fourth Test, but Brown was not recalled to open with Morris; instead, Hassett was promoted to open with Morris, while the teenaged Harvey came into the middle-order. Although Hassett failed with only 13 and 17 in his two innings, Harvey struck 112 in the first innings,<ref name=sco4/> before Australia chased down 404 on the final day to set a world record for the highest successful run-chase in Test cricket and won by seven wickets.<ref name=report4>{{Cite web|title= Fourth Test Match England v Australia |work= [[Wisden Cricketers' Almanack]] |year=1949 |url=http://www.cricinfo.com/wisdenalmanack/content/story/152897.html |accessdate=2008-07-02 |publisher=[[Wisden]]}}</ref>
Brown partnered the recovered Barnes and patiently scored 140, before being the fifth man out with the score at 344, as Australia amassed 456 and defeated [[Derbyshire County Cricket Club|Derbyshire]] by an innings immediately after the Fourth Test.<ref name=sched/><ref name=derby>{{Cite web |url = http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/18/18616.html |title = Derbyshire v Australians |publisher = [[CricketArchive]] |accessdate = 2007-12-26}}</ref> Looking to regain his Test position by sheer weight of runs, Brown started slowly; Barnes made 24 of the first 29 runs.<ref name=derby/> He took 185 minutes to reach 50, much to the displeasure of the restless spectators, before accelerating and scoring his next 50 runs in 37 minutes.<ref>Fingleton, p. 200.</ref>
In the next match against [[Glamorgan County Cricket Club|Glamorgan]], Brown scored 16 in a rain-affected draw that did not reach the second innings.<ref name=o/><ref name=sched/> He scored 33 and seven in the following match, falling both times to the [[leg spin]] of [[Eric Hollies]] as Australia defeated [[Warwickshire County Cricket Club|Warwickshire]] by nine wickets.<ref name=o/> Brown was then rested as Australia faced and drew with Lancashire for the second time on the tour. He returned for the non-first-class match against [[Durham County Cricket Club|Durham]], scoring 49 out of Australia's 282 in a weather-affected draw that failed to reach the second innings.<ref name=sched/><ref name="durham"/> Brown was overlooked for selection in the Fifth Test at [[The Oval]]. Barnes returned to the team and Australia crushed England by an innings and 149 runs to take the series 4–0 after cutting them down for only 52 in the first innings.<ref name=sco5/><ref name="report5">{{Cite web|title= Fifth Test Match England v Australia |work= [[Wisden Cricketers' Almanack]] |year=1949 |url=http://www.cricinfo.com/wisdenalmanack/content/story/152898.html |accessdate=2008-07-02 |publisher=[[Wisden]]}}</ref>
==Later tour matches== [[File:Arthur Morris.jpg|thumb|Arthur Morris (pictured), one of Brown's opening partners during the tour.]]
Seven matches remained on Bradman's quest to go through a tour of England without defeat.<ref name=sched/> Australia batted first against [[Kent County Cricket Club|Kent]] and Brown top-scored with 106. After putting on 64 with Morris for the first wicket, he put on 104 each for the next two partnerships with Bradman and Harvey respectively, before falling at 3/272.<ref name=kent/> Brown again batted slowly; he took 255 minutes to reach triple figures and was greeted by ironic clapping as he slowly accumulated runs while his partners attacked.<ref name="Fingleton, p. 207">Fingleton, p. 207.</ref> Brown's dismissal triggered a collapse; Australia lost their last seven wickets for 89 to end at 361.<ref name=kent>{{Cite web |url = http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/18/18674.html |title = Kent v Australians |publisher = [[CricketArchive]] |accessdate = 2007-12-26}}</ref> Despite this, they completed another innings victory.<ref name=o/> In the next match against the [[Gentlemen of England cricket team|Gentlemen of England]], which was held at Lord's, Brown scored 120, featuring in a 180-run second wicket partnership with Bradman, as Australia amassed 5/610 and won by an innings.<ref name=gents>{{Cite web |url = http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/18/18684.html |title = Gentlemen v Australians |publisher = [[CricketArchive]] |accessdate = 2007-12-26}}</ref> Former Australian Test opener and batting partner [[Jack Fingleton]] said "Brown has always looked the class batsman that he is when playing at Lord's, and this superb century, so different in conception and execution to the one at [[Canterbury]] [against Kent], made one reflect what a grand opening batsman this series of Tests had done without".<ref>Fingleton, pp. 207–208.</ref> Fingleton made a duck in the next match but Australia nevertheless defeated [[Somerset County Cricket Club|Somerset]] by an innings and 374 runs.<ref name=o/><ref name=sched/> He then made 13 against the [[South of England cricket team|South of England]] in his last first-class match of the season. The match was washed out, but not before Brown took 4/16 from 4.1 overs in his only first-class bowling effort of the tour, cleaning up the tail.<ref name=o/><ref name=sched/>
Australia's biggest challenge in the post-Test tour matches was against the Leveson-Gower's XI. During the last Australian tour in 1938, the team was effectively a full-strength England outfit, but this time Bradman insisted only six England players from the season's Tests be allowed to compete.<ref name=plg/><ref>Fingleton, pp. 207–209.</ref> After his opponents had finalised their team, Bradman fielded a full-strength team,<ref name=plg>Perry (2005), pp. 253–254.</ref> and Brown missed out. The match ended in a draw after multiple rain delays.<ref name=sco5/><ref name=lg>{{Cite web |url = http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/18/18706.html |title = H.D.G. Leveson-Gower's XI v Australians |publisher = [[CricketArchive]] |accessdate = 2008-12-18}}</ref>
The tour ended with two non-first-class matches against [[Scotland national cricket team|Scotland]]. In the first match, Brown was rested as the Australians claimed an innings victory. In the second match, Brown scored 24 not out batting at No. 8 and took a wicket in the second innings as Australia ended the tour with another innings victory.<ref name=o/><ref name=sched/>
==Role== [[Image:Bill Brown graph 1948.png|300px|right|thumb|A chart showing Brown's batting performance during the tour. The runs scored per innings are represented by the bars, with the red bars being Test innings and the pink bars being other first-class innings. The blue line is the average of the five most recent innings and the dots indicate [[not out]]s.<ref name=o/>]]
An experienced right-handed opening batsman, Brown was on his third campaign in England, having first toured in 1934 before the [[World War II]]. However, Brown's best years were lost to the war and by 1948,<ref name=az>{{Cite book| last = Cashman, Richard; Franks, Warwick; [[Jim Maxwell (commentator)|Maxwell, Jim]]; Sainsbury, Erica; Stoddart, Brian; Weaver, Amanda; Webster, Ray | year = 1997 | title = The AâZ of Australian cricketers| isbn=0-9756746-1-7|location=Melbourne, Victoria |publisher=Oxford University Press |page=67}}</ref> Barnes and Morris had risen above him in the pecking order and become Australia's first-choice opening pair.<ref name=sco1/><ref name=sco2/><ref name=sco3/><ref name=sco4/><ref name=sco5/> Brown was selected as the reserve opener, a decision that generated controversy among pundits who believed he was past his best.<ref name=f70>Fingleton, p. 70.</ref><ref name=f194>Fingleton, p. 194.</ref>
During the tour matches, which were usually played consecutively with only one or no days between fixtures,<ref name=sched/> Bradman rotated the trio of openers, so one would generally be rested while the other two opened,<sup><span style="color:#00f">N-</span></sup>{{Ref label|bat|1|a}} but in the Tests, Morris and Barnes were preferred.<ref name=sco1/><ref name=sco2/><ref name=sco3/><ref name=sco4/><ref name=sco5/> Bradman accommodated Brown in his first-choice team by playing him out of position in the middle order in the first two Tests and against Worcestershire and the MCC, when he fielded the strongest XI.<ref name=worcs/><ref name=mcc/> However, Brown appeared uncomfortable in the unfamiliar role, and after making 73 runs at 24.33 in the first two Tests, he was dropped.<ref name=sco1/><ref name=sco2/><ref name=f91>Fingleton, p. 91.</ref><ref name=fc/>
Nevertheless, Brown was successful in the tour matches when he played as an opener. He ended the tour with eight centuries and a total of 1,448 first-class runs at an average of 57.92,<ref name="tel">{{Cite news |title=Bill Brown |url= http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/1581980/Bill-Brown.html |date=2008-03-18 |accessdate=2008-06-10 |work = [[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]}}</ref> behind only Bradman, Hassett and Morris in the runs and averages, with a highest score of 200 against Cambridge University.<ref name="az"/><ref name="old">{{Cite web|url=http://www.cricinfo.com/ci/content/story/70460.html| title='What did you do at Lord's, Grandpa?'| first=David |last=Frith|authorlink=David Frith|accessdate=2007-12-06|work=Wisden Cricket Monthly |year=1987|publisher=[[Cricinfo]]}}</ref> Brown's tally of eight centuries was second only to Bradman,<ref name=fc/> and took his tally on English soil to 18 first-class tons.<ref name=times>{{Cite web| title=Bill Brown: Accomplished batsman who scored handsomely for Australia before and after the war |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/comment/obituaries/article3570490.ece | first=Derek |last=Hodgson |date=2008-03-18 |accessdate=2008-06-24 |work = [[The Times]] | location=London}}</ref> Excluding the matches against Worcestershire, the MCC and the first two Tests, in which Brown had scored 25, 26, 17, 24 and 32 batting in the middle order while Barnes and Morris opened,<ref name=worcs/><ref name=sco1/><ref name=sco2/><ref name=mcc/> Brown scored 1,324 runs at 66.20 while opening in the other matches, which would have put him in a clear fourth place on the batting averages.<ref name=fc>{{Cite web| url=http://stats.cricinfo.com/ci/engine/records/averages/batting_bowling.html?class=4;id=1070;type=tour |publisher=[[Cricinfo]] |title=Batting and bowling averages Australia tour of England, Apr-Sep 1948 – First-class matches|accessdate=2008-12-10}}</ref> Following his omission from the Test team midway through the tour, Brown batted in a slow and conservative manner in order to score more runs and regain his position, much to the chagrin of the crowds.<ref name="Fingleton, p. 207"/>
A very occasional [[off spin]]ner,<ref name=az/> Brown took 4/16 against the South of England in his only first-class bowling assignment of the tour.<ref>{{Cite book | title = [[Wisden Cricketers' Almanack]] | edition = 1949 | publisher = [[Wisden]] | chapter = Australians in England, 1948 | pages = 257–258 }}</ref> It was his best career bowling figures—he accumulated only six wickets in his first-class career.<ref name="az"/> He also took 18 catches in the first-class fixtures.<ref name=o/>
